code: @Manual{,   title = {minter: Meta-analysis of interactions},   author = {Facundo Decunta},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.0.1},   url = {https://fdecunta.github.io/minter/}, }

title: Meta-analysis of interactions
text: Helper functions conducting meta-analyses interactions 2×2 factorial experiments.

title: Meta-analysis of interactions
text: can install development version minter GitHub :

title: Meta-analysis of interactions
text: can compute bunch effect sizes one function: non-independence sampling variances exists, may use estimated variance-covariance matrix. multiple effect sizes need multiple matrices. can one call: use one matrices, reference using ‘$’:
code: library(minter)  data(fake_data)  # Compute the effect sizes fake_data <- inter_effsize(   effsize = "lnrr",   colnames = c("Herb", "Fert"),   data = fake_data,   Ctrl_mean = C_mean,   Ctrl_sd = C_sd,   Ctrl_n = C_n,   A_mean = Herb_mean,   A_sd = Herb_sd,   A_n = Herb_n,   B_mean = Fert_mean,   B_sd = Fert_sd,   B_n = Fert_n,   AB_mean = HxF_mean,   AB_sd = HxF_sd,   AB_n = HxF_n )  str(fake_data) #> 'data.frame':    9 obs. of  24 variables: #>  $ Study                : chr  "Study_1" "Study_1" "Study_2" "Study_3" ... #>  $ C_mean               : num  8.46 8.75 8.2 11.33 10.6 ... #>  $ C_sd                 : num  1.48 1.27 1.56 1.91 1.9 ... #>  $ C_n                  : int  23 26 23 20 27 23 28 27 25 #>  $ Herb_mean            : num  10.9 10.1 10.7 12.9 13.1 ... #>  $ Herb_sd              : num  1.4 1.48 1.56 1.7 1.92 ... #>  $ Herb_n               : int  27 29 23 24 26 20 27 27 29 #>  $ Fert_mean            : num  9.7 11.47 11.16 9.08 10.86 ... #>  $ Fert_sd              : num  1.02 1.5 1.87 1.01 1.07 ... #>  $ Fert_n               : int  30 30 28 23 29 26 28 26 29 #>  $ HxF_mean             : num  11 10.8 12.9 11.1 15.4 ... #>  $ HxF_sd               : num  1.63 1.48 1.16 1.01 1.45 ... #>  $ HxF_n                : int  28 23 25 21 20 24 28 23 22 #>  $ EffectSize_ID        : int  1 2 3 4 5 6 7 8 9 #>  $ Herb_simple_lnRR     : num  0.251 0.145 0.263 0.13 0.208 ... #>  $ Herb_simple_lnRR_var : num  0.00194 0.00154 0.00251 0.00215 0.00202 ... #>  $ Fert_simple_lnRR     : num  0.136 0.271 0.308 -0.2216 0.0239 ... #>  $ Fert_simple_lnRR_var : num  0.0017 0.00138 0.00259 0.00196 0.00153 ... #>  $ Herb_overall_lnRR    : num  0.1852 0.0334 0.1987 0.1615 0.2813 ... #>  $ Herb_overall_lnRR_var: num  0.000744 0.000725 0.000904 0.000839 0.000682 ... #>  $ Fert_overall_lnRR    : num  0.066 0.166 0.245 -0.184 0.103 ... #>  $ Fert_overall_lnRR_var: num  0.000751 0.000729 0.000904 0.000744 0.000703 ... #>  $ Herb_x_Fert_lnRR     : num  -0.128 -0.2051 -0.1153 0.0688 0.1398 ... #>  $ Herb_x_Fert_lnRR_var : num  0.0031 0.00293 0.00384 0.00308 0.0028 ... vi_cols <- c(   "Herb_simple_lnRR_var",   "Fert_simple_lnRR_var",   "Herb_overall_lnRR_var",   "Fert_overall_lnRR_var",   "Herb_x_Fert_lnRR_var" )  VCVs <- inter_vcv(   vi_cols = vi_cols,   cluster = Study,   obs = EffectSize_ID,   rho = 0.5,   data = fake_data )  str(VCVs) #> List of 5 #>  $ Herb_simple_lnRR_var : num [1:9, 1:9] 0.001941 0.000865 0 0 0 ... #>  $ Fert_simple_lnRR_var : num [1:9, 1:9] 0.001701 0.000765 0 0 0 ... #>  $ Herb_overall_lnRR_var: num [1:9, 1:9] 0.000744 0.000367 0 0 0 ... #>  $ Fert_overall_lnRR_var: num [1:9, 1:9] 0.000751 0.00037 0 0 0 ... #>  $ Herb_x_Fert_lnRR_var : num [1:9, 1:9] 0.0031 0.00151 0 0 0 ... res <- metafor::rma.mv(   yi = Herb_x_Fert_lnRR,   V  = VCVs$Herb_x_Fert_lnRR_var,   random = ~ 1 | Study,   test = "t",   data = fake_data)  res #>  #> Multivariate Meta-Analysis Model (k = 9; method: REML) #>  #> Variance Components: #>  #>             estim    sqrt  nlvls  fixed  factor  #> sigma^2    0.0329  0.1814      5     no   Study  #>  #> Test for Heterogeneity: #> Q(df = 8) = 89.2014, p-val < .0001 #>  #> Model Results: #>  #> estimate      se     tval  df    pval    ci.lb   ci.ub     #>  -0.1266  0.0842  -1.5036   8  0.1711  -0.3207  0.0675     #>  #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

title: Compute interaction effect sizes — inter_effsize
text: effsize Character. Effect‐size metric compute. Supported: "lnrr". colnames Character vector length 2 giving names use factors B Ctrl_mean Mean outcome Control treatment Ctrl_sd Standard deviation control treatment Ctrl_n Sample size control streatment A_mean Mean outcome treatment A_sd Standard deviation treatment A_n Sample size treatment B_mean Mean outcome B treatment B_sd Standard deviation B treatment B_n Sample size B treatment AB_mean Mean outcome interaction AxB treatment AB_sd Standard deviation interaction AxB treatment AB_n Sample size interaction AxB treatment data Data fram data.

title: Compute interaction effect sizes — inter_effsize
text: original data effect size variance appended, named colnames.

title: Compute interaction effect sizes — inter_effsize
text: Facundo Decunta - fdecunta@agro.uba.ar

title: Compute interaction effect sizes — inter_effsize
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ result <- inter_effsize(   effsize   = "lnrr",   data      = df,   colnames  = c("yi", "vi"),   Ctrl_mean = ctrl_mean, Ctrl_sd = ctrl_sd, Ctrl_n = ctrl_n,   A_mean    = a_mean,    A_sd    = a_sd,    A_n    = a_n,   B_mean    = b_mean,    B_sd    = b_sd,    B_n    = b_n,   AB_mean   = ab_mean,   AB_sd   = ab_sd,   AB_n   = ab_n, ) } # }

what: Compute variance–covariance matrices for correlated sampling variances — inter_vcv
title: Compute variance–covariance matrices for correlated sampling variances — inter_vcv
text: Get multiple VCV matrices .

title: Compute variance–covariance matrices for correlated sampling variances — inter_vcv
Compute variance–covariance matrices for correlated sampling variances — inter_vcv
text: vi_cols Character vector. Names sampling-variance columns (e.g., "vi") VCV matrices computed. cluster Character string. Name column data identifies clustering unit (example, study ID). obs Character string. Name column indexing individual observations (effect sizes) within cluster. rho Numeric. Assumed intra-class correlation (0 1) used metafor::vcalc fill -diagonals. data data.frame containing cols, cluster, obs. ... Additional arguments passed straight metafor::vcalc.

title: Compute variance–covariance matrices for correlated sampling variances — inter_vcv
text: Quickly obtain one variance–covariance matrices account non-independence coming study, experiment, clustering unit. function thin wrapper around vcalc, looping columns listed cols returning resulting VCV matrices named list.

title: Compute variance–covariance matrices for correlated sampling variances — inter_vcv
text: Facundo Decunta - fdecunta@agro.uba.ar
